Heart disorders are the focus of the medical specialty of cardiology. Cardiologists are medical professionals with specialized training in this area. They have received training in the diagnosis and management of cardiac disorders including valvular heart disease, congenital heart illnesses, infections, infarctions, and heart failure.

There are several cardiovascular system problems that require specialized care and clinical knowledge to manage. Angina pectoris, atherosclerosis, acute coronary syndrome, coronary heart disease, and restenosis are a few of them.

Other common conditions include cardiac arrest, cardiomyopathy, pericarditis, diseases of the aortic, mitral, pulmonary, and tricuspid valves, congenital heart defects like an atrial or ventricular septal defect, and a few vascular diseases like deep vein thrombosis.

Why choose Hope Hospitals for cardiology?

Our contemporary lifestyle renders us vulnerable to many different heart conditions, but by making small lifestyle modifications, it is possible to prevent or delay the beginning of many heart conditions.Our cardiac diagnostic team is equipped with cutting-edge screening technology including ECG, Echocardiogram, Stress test, and Angiography because an accurate diagnosis is always the first step toward a cure. With a fully-stocked ICU and operating room, the cardiology department staff is prepared to handle any emergency circumstance.

Our Hope Hospital team is dedicated to the medical and surgical treatment of all cardiac conditions, including cardiac rehabilitation and primary and secondary prevention.

Signs of heart diseases

  • Changes in the heart rhythm
  • Shortness of breath
  • Elevated levels of blood pressure
  • Dizziness
  • A heart attack is indicated by pain in the left hand, jaw, or neck.
  • Chest pain

Conditions we treat

  • Hypertension
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Angina pectoris
  • Arrhythmias
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Pericarditis
  • High blood triglycerides and cholesterol
  • Tachycardia
  • Bradycardia
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Congenital heart disease

Services for heart disease diagnostic testing that we offer

  • Blood test
  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
  • Electrocardiogram (ECG)
  • Stress test
  • Ambulatory ECG
  • Pulmonary angiography
  • Electrophysiology of heart
  • Cardiac catheterisation
  • Aortography

Treatments we provide for heart diseases

  • Thoracic surgeries Having a heart valve repaired, a lung tumor removed, or having a chest aneurysm repaired.
  • Heart valve surgery is a minimally invasive surgery to replace an inadequately opening narrowing aortic valve (aortic valve stenosis). A catheter is inserted into the leg or chest and directed to the heart during this surgery by surgeons.
  • Aneurysm surgery is used to treat aortic aneurysms. Your aorta’s damaged section is removed by a surgeon, and it is then replaced with a graft, a synthetic fabric tube.
  • Vascular surgery that can be used to address a variety of blood flow and heart conditions.
  • Coronary artery bypass surgery is a surgical method for the treatment of coronary heart disease. It redirects blood past constricted or blocked areas of the major arteries to increase the heart’s blood flow and oxygenation.
  • Angioplasty or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty, is an endovascular treatment used to treat arterial atherosclerosis by expanding restricted or blocked arteries or veins with the use of a catheter. It involves performing surgery to unblock or repair a blood vessel, particularly a coronary artery.
  • Non-surgical valve replacements The patient’s natural aortic valve is replaced with an artificial one using a catheter threaded through an artery.
  • Cardioversion is a medical treatment that reestablishes a regular cardiac rhythm using brief, low-energy shocks.
  • Pacemaker implantation is a tiny device that is implanted in the chest to assist in heartbeat regulation.
  • Angiography is an X-ray technique used to examine blood vessels.

Ways to keep your heart healthy

  1. Reduce salt intake: High blood pressure increases heart disease risk. A heart-healthy diet reduces salt. Also, ready-to-eat foods are high in salt.
  2. Central Obesity: Excess belly fat elevates the risk of developing diabetes and heart disease. Excess abdominal fat can increase health risks in normal-weight people. 
  3. Exercise: The heart needs exercise. 30 minutes of exercise five days a week. Do something—walk, jog, do yoga, join a gym, play your favorite sport.
  4. Quit smoking: It’s healthiest for your heart to quit smoking. Smoking increases heart disease risk by 2–4 times! Quit smoking today for a healthy, active life.
  5. High blood pressure is the leading cause of brain stroke and over half of all heart disorders. Eat healthy, avoid sodium, exercise, and maintain a healthy weight to lower blood pressure.
  6. Manage Diabetes: Type 2 diabetes increases the risk of heart disease and brain stroke by two to four times. Make healthy lifestyle adjustments to manage your diabetes. Maintaining a healthy weight is crucial for diabetics.
  7. Family history matters: If any female under 45 or male under 50 has had a heart attack, your risk of heart disease doubles. Since prevention is better than cure, see a cardiac specialist periodically.

Oil’s Importance: Extra virgin olive oil is heart-healthy. It should only be used in salads and dips, not cooked or fried. Regular oils have different nutrients, so replace them every six months for improved health.

 

What is cardiac failure? Does a transplant seem necessary?

If the heart cannot effectively fill (diastolic) or pump (systolic), heart failure may result. An operation called a heart transplant involves replacing a sick heart with a donor heart that is in better health. Treatments like heart transplants are typically only given to patients whose conditions haven’t improved enough with drugs or other procedures.

 

What signs indicate a heart attack?

Usually, a fainting spell or loss of consciousness coupled with an abrupt drop in heartbeat is the first indication of a heart attack. Before the incident, some people may have had chest pain, nausea, dizziness, or nauseousness. The best course of action is to see a doctor.

 

What contributes to heart issues?

You are at risk of developing heart issues for a number of reasons. One is more likely to get heart disease if they are obese, suffer from high levels of stress and blood pressure, have pre-existing illnesses like Type 2 Diabetes, have high cholesterol, smoke, or drink alcohol frequently. For healthy adults over the age of 30, we advise annual health exams and medical consultations.

 

How do stress tests work?

Stress testing can detect coronary artery blockage. Workload is gradually increased under electrocardiographic monitoring. Heart rate determines the exam level. Stress testing often involves echocardiography or nuclear heart muscle scanning. These strategies improve diagnosis. Patients with symptoms or numerous risk factors are routinely tested for coronary artery disease.

 

How do strokes occur?

Brain tissue dies from bleeding or blood supply disruption in a stroke. Blood flow interruption causes most adult strokes. Due to vascular dysfunction, particulate matter from neck arteries, the big aorta in the chest, or the heart might embolize or flow into the brain and cause a stroke. This may be clotted blood or cholesterol fragments. Stroke is the most common complication of uncontrolled hypertension.
